subtitle: Sing to your baby, he can hear you!
description: Sing to your baby, he can hear you!
title: Month 6
content:
Created by BabyCenter Inside your womb, your baby wakes and sleeps at regular
intervals now. He can now open and close his eyes, and suck his finger or
thumb! This helps develop his sucking muscles so that he is strong enough to
feed as soon as he is born. His brain is growing and developing quickly now.
He can respond to sound now. At first, he will only hear sounds from your
body, like your heartbeat. But slowly he will start to hear noises from
outside your body. Sing to your baby so he can hear your voice. It may feel
like your womb is up near your ribcage, which will make you feel out of
breath. Eating can be difficult because your stomach may be squeezed by your
growing baby. Have small meals more often and snacks between meals. As your
baby grows so does your womb. The skin over your belly stretches and this can
itch. You may notice red streaks on your tummy, hips, bottom and breasts. They
are stretch marks and they will fade to faint marks after you give birth. You
may have leg cramps or swollen veins. Your breasts are fuller and heavier now.
This is because they are getting ready to make milk for your baby.
